Situation1: They notice a mentee struggling with time management during casual check-ins.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story:
I sat at my desk, headset on, toggling between two worlds. As a mentor, I prided myself on nurturing growth, always ready to listen and guide. Just this morning, I noticed my mentee, Jamie, seemed frazzled, her calendar a mess of overlapping meetings. I wanted to help her find balance, to encourage her to prioritize and breathe. But as the clock struck noon, I switched roles—now, I was a telemarketer, my job to sell, to stick to the script, to handle objections with practiced ease.

The calls came fast. Prospects peppered me with technical questions about our new service, questions the script barely touched. I felt the urge to go off-script, to explain, to teach—just as I would with Jamie. But my supervisor’s voice echoed in my mind: “Stick to the script. Don’t get sidetracked.” I felt torn, the mentor in me itching to help, the telemarketer in me bound by rules. My heart pounded as I stared at the blinking cursor, caught between the urge to nurture and the demand to perform.
